awd_titl_txt: ABI:  Development:  Bringing Supercomputing to the Desktop: New Capabilities for Phylogenetic Inference in the Era of Data-Driven Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of California, San Diego (La Jolla, CA) has received an ABI development award to create the CIPRES REST API (CRA), a set of enabling public web services for the biology community. The CRA will make it possible for any biologist with modest programming skills to access and run powerful phylogenetic tools on NSF XSEDE supercomputers from within their preferred work environment. The project will embed the CRA into eight distinct software environments that are widely used in the biology community, providing direct access to supercomputing resources from within these familiar working environments. The CRA will make it possible for scientists to analyze much larger data sets than is currently possible without changing their normal work environment or learning to use new software. Community developers will be able to incorporate the CRA tools into their software environments in new and creative ways. The tools created by this project are an extension of the prototype CIPRES Science Gateway, a web application that allows researchers to run large phylogenetic analyses on NSF XSEDE computing resources through a standard browser interface. In its first 30 months of operation, the CIPRES Science Gateway has run analyses for more than 5,000 users, enabled 400+ scholarly publications in biological disciplines ranging from Ecology to Virology, and was used by at least 68 instructors for curriculum delivery.

The impact of CIPRES Science Gateway prototype has been profound because understanding the evolutionary history of living organisms is central to all fields of biological research, and evolutionary relationships are explored primarily by comparing DNA and protein sequences using computationally intensive algorithms. The rate of DNA and protein sequence acquisition is currently increasing more rapidly than Moore's law. While this represents an unprecedented opportunity to clarify evolutionary relationships, it also means routine analyses can no longer be conducted with laptop/desktop computers.  Researchers must have easy access to high performance computing (HPC) resources to participate in the discovery process. The CRA will improve the efficiency of access to computational resources by shifting from the rigid browser paradigm of the CIPRES Science Gateway to a pervasive access model, where the phylogenetic tools required for modern biological research are available from within the researcher's preferred environment. The software and techniques created will be completely generic and easily adapted to any area of science where progress is limited by access to computational resources. More information about this project can be obtained from http://www.phylo.org/index.php/portal/  or mmiller@sdsc.edu.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding evolutionary relationships is an essential part of all biological investigation. New DNA sequencing techniques have dramatically increased the amount of data available to clarify evolutionary relationships, but this wealth of data can only be interpreted through access to phylogenetics codes run on powerful computational resources. The CIPRES Science Gateway (CIPRES) was created as browser-based point of access that allow researchers to run commonly used phylogenetic analysis software on high performance computers. CIPRES was heavily accessed from its initial launch, and supported a significant increase in the rate of discovery using phylogenetic tools, as measured both  by the number of researcher who used CIPRES, the number of jobs run, and the number publications.

Intellectual Merit:  The project supported the continued evolution of CIPRES as a public resource, and it supported the creation of a new set of RESTful web services. The web services created make it possible to incorporate access to all of the CIPRES capabilities through existing and new desktop and from web-based applications. The project supported 20,000 researchers in accessing resource to analyze their data. Users were able to run their jobs more quickly, and they were able to run more jobs concurrently than they would have been able to do on their local resources. Ninety-three percent of CIPRES users reported the resource has a material benefit to their research, and 84% said that without CIPRES, their work would have proceeded more slowly, or it would not have occurred at all. The RESTful services have been incorporated into several other web applications, including the Virus Pathogen Resource, the Influenza research database, a Galaxy Implementation at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, MorphoBank, and the Tree-Based Alignment Selector Gateway (T-BAS). The REST services have also been incorporated into several community software packages, including raxmlGUI and Mesquite/Zephyr. The project also support the creation of a distributable software framework that can be used to create science gateways. Three new gateways have been created using this software.  

Broad Impacts: The CIPRES project had broad impacts because creating and a platform for easy access to supercomputing resources makes it possible for under-resourced researchers worldwide to participate more fully in the discovery process. The access model we created here should help to drive policy discussions in the US and abroad about how computational resources should be accessed and allocated to scientists globally. The project improved infrastructure by promoting formation of an open source community to improve and sustain the software package created to provide access, and by establishing ongoing collaborations with seven distinct projects distributed over five institutions. The project promoted training and learning globally by providing a platform for curriculum delivery that has been used by 100+ instructors. The project promoted training and learning locally by employing several graduate and undergraduate students on the development staff, and will broaden participation by training two interns in each year from minority-serving community colleges.
